instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .

threads.title: 00165 liquid - <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> :(
threads.message:
00165 board with liquid damage

MagSafe but no fan

F7140 had 8.6v on pin 1 and 0.2v on pin2 but it wasn't blown

Stuck 5v onto pin 2 to see if anything warmed up. 

<CHIP>U7310</CHIP> was getting warm so swapped that, then I noticed <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> on the other side was also getting warm. Swapped it and now PPBUS is stable but will <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> have f'd the CPU in the ass or is there a chance it survived the sodomy?

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.58v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5.01v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.31v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.43v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.31v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.31v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.42v

<SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>PP15V_TBT</SIGNAL> = 0v

<TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR>
Pin 4 = 8.58v
Pin 1 = 8.12v
Pin 2-3 = 0v

threads.title: 00165 liquid - <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> :(
threads.message: No point in trying to get S4 going then. I’ll use it for parts if there’s no chance with this one.

threads.title: 00165 liquid - <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> :(
threads.message:
I don’t suppose there’s a way of confirming a dead cpu is there? Like a certain output or whatever.

or is 8.6v up it enough of a confirmation

threads.title: 00165 liquid - <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> :(
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> shorted that is enough confirmation lol. Sent 8 volts to the CPU and killed it instantly.

threads.title: 00165 liquid - <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> :(
threads.message: Yeah figured as much. I’ve got a few more 00165’s to do anyway so at least now I have extra spares.
